hints_html:
First, use the fact from part (b) that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac1{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots\end{aligned}\]

provided r < 1, to get the power series of \(\ln(1-r)\) per integration. Then make a proper substitution for r.
hints_latex:
First, use the fact from
{part
(b)} that

\begin{align*}
\frac1{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots
\end{align*} provided
\textbar{}\emph{r}\textbar{} \textless{} 1, to get the power series of
$\ln(1-r)$ per integration. Then make a proper substitution for
\emph{r}.
hints_raw:
First, use the fact from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH105/April_2012/Question_01_(b)|part (b)]] that
:<math>
\frac1{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots
</math>
provided |''r''| < 1, to get the power series of <math>\ln(1-r)</math> per integration. Then make a proper substitution for ''r''.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
For r<1 we use that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots\end{aligned}\]

and integrate both sides to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} -\ln|1-r| &= \int \frac{1}{1-r} dr \\ &= \int(1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots) dr \\ &= r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + ... + C\end{aligned}\]

Since r < 1 we have 1-r = 1-r, therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -\ln(1-r) = r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + \dots + C\end{aligned}\]

To solve for the integration constant C we plug in r = 0:

\[\begin{aligned} -\ln(1-r) &= -\ln 1 = 0 \\ &= 0 + 0^2/2 + 0^3/3 + 0^4/4 + ... + C = C\end{aligned}\]

so C = 0.

So we obtain the intermediate result that

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(1-r) = -r - r^2/2 - r^3/3 - r^4/4 + \dots = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k/k.\end{aligned}\]

To arrive at the summation notation, we noted that every term has the same sign (so there are no terms like \((-1)^k\) floating around), every integer power of \(r\) is included starting from \(r^1\), and each \(r^k\) is divided by k.

As a last step, the Taylor series for \(\ln(1+2x)\) can be found by replacing \(r\) by \(-2x\) in the series above. We find:

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(1+2x) = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-2x)^k}{k}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
For \textbar{}\emph{r}\textbar{}\textless{}1 we use that

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots
\end{align*} and integrate both sides
to obtain

\begin{align*}
-\ln|1-r| &= \int \frac{1}{1-r} dr \\
&= \int(1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots) dr \\
&= r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + ... + C
\end{align*}

Since \textbar{}\emph{r}\textbar{} \textless{} 1 we have
\textbar{}1-\emph{r}\textbar{} = 1-\emph{r}, therefore

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-\ln(1-r) = r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + \dots + C
\end{align*}

To solve for the integration constant \emph{C} we plug in \emph{r} = 0:

\begin{align*}
-\ln(1-r) &= -\ln 1 = 0 \\
&= 0 + 0^2/2 + 0^3/3 + 0^4/4 + ... + C = C
\end{align*} so \emph{C} = 0.

So we obtain the intermediate result that

\begin{align*}
\ln(1-r) = -r - r^2/2 - r^3/3 - r^4/4 + \dots = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k/k.
\end{align*}

To arrive at the summation notation, we noted that every term has the
same sign (so there are no terms like $(-1)^k$ floating around), every
integer power of $r$ is included starting from $r^1$, and each $r^k$ is
divided by \emph{k}.

As a last step, the Taylor series for $\ln(1+2x)$ can be found by
replacing $r$ by $-2x$ in the series above. We find:

\begin{align*}
\ln(1+2x) = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-2x)^k}{k}.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
For |''r''|<1 we use that
:<math>
\frac{1}{1-r} = 1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots
</math>
and integrate both sides to obtain
:<math>
\begin{align}
-\ln|1-r| &= \int \frac{1}{1-r} dr \\
&= \int(1 + r + r^2 + r^3 + \dots) dr \\
&= r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + ... + C
\end{align}
</math>

Since |''r''| < 1  we have |1-''r''| = 1-''r'', therefore
:<math>\displaystyle
-\ln(1-r) = r + r^2/2 + r^3/3 + r^4/4 + \dots + C
</math>

To solve for the integration constant ''C'' we plug in ''r'' = 0:
:<math>
\begin{align}
-\ln(1-r) &= -\ln 1 = 0 \\
&= 0 + 0^2/2 + 0^3/3 + 0^4/4 + ... + C = C
\end{align}
</math>
so ''C'' = 0.

So we obtain the intermediate result that
:<math>
\begin{align}
\ln(1-r) = -r - r^2/2 - r^3/3 - r^4/4 + \dots = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k/k.
\end{align}
</math> 

To arrive at the summation notation, we noted that every term has the same sign (so there are no terms like <math>(-1)^k</math> floating around), every integer power of <math>r</math> is included starting from <math>r^1</math>, and each <math>r^k</math> is divided by ''k''.

As a last step, the Taylor series for <math>\ln(1+2x)</math> can be found by replacing <math>r</math> by <math>-2x</math> in the series above. We find:

:<math>\ln(1+2x) = - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-2x)^k}{k}</math>.
statement_html:
Express the Taylor series of the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln(1+2x)\end{aligned}\]

about x = 0 in summation notation.
statement_raw:
Express the Taylor series of the function

:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \ln(1+2x)
</math>

about ''x = 0'' in summation notation.
